messageBody:
Thanks for the example in design issues... but that isn't what I was after.
I should have been more clear, and I will be next time.

The real issue of this sub-thread is in where to locate tests and why. The
original quote (paraphrased) was that "we put tests in the same package as
production code to make it easier to test protected interfaces of our
objects." I don't see where this fits in to good design or good testing
practices. The virtue of public/protected/private/default is not what I was
questioning. I wanted to point out the potential flaws of design and
testing that could otherwise be missed when you put tests in the same
package as production code. The production code should be tested in the
same fashion it would be used by a client. A test is a client in some
degree. In most cases clients exist outside of the package.

Someone (sorry, I forget who it was) brought up the fact that "client" is a
loose term that can refer to objects outside my package domain as well as to
objects within my package domain. I do not disagree with that assertion.
However, I believe that (in most cases) the public interface of any part of
a system should be designed in such a way that when it is tested the
programmer can be assured that he/she hasn't broken anything. The
package-scope clients usually have a public interface of their own which can
then be tested separately from the classes they interact with. Often times
in a situation where objects use the protected "inners" (either variables or
methods) of another object within their package there is some kind of
heirarchical relationship where one object is a supporter of another. Thus,
I conclude, that testing the public interfaces of ALL objects (the key being
ALL) should prove sufficient, thus not needing the tests to reside in the
same package as their associated production code objects. Of course, there
are exceptions... we have ways around those.

-Jason

I could, but that would cost you more then 2c #:-)

consider, as an example, the following pattern:

abstract class A {
public void doSomeThingComplex() {
// do some stuff
:
// call extender's code
doSomeThingSimple();
// do some more stuff
:
}

protected abstract void doSomeThingSimple();
}

public class B extends A {
protected void doSomeThingSimple(){
// do it
}
}

- but this is turning into a thread on Java design issues, maybe we should
take it elsewhere.

Yishay
